title: Early rehabilitation in patients with stroke

author: Aleš Pražnikar, Nevrološka klinika, Univerzitetni Klinični Center Ljubljana

segmentation: My name is Alex freshman.
Can I come from neurological clinic Indiana?
So early rehabilitation in patients with stroke is a demanding lecture and I will actually not give electron early rehabilitation as such, but more my comments and our experiences with it.
So we are not very good at healing the stroke.
A lot of patients stay disabled in different ways.
And.
It looks like that the burden of stroke will be even greater in future.
In Ljubljana's neurologic clinic we admit about.
1500 patients with stroke every year.
And the trend is going on.
It's not so much because of the incident.
It has much to do that we have become a Center for trim back to me, and so the patients are draining in from all over the country.
Our.
Department for stroke has 60 beds.
10 beds are for intensive care treatment.
And.
Just some of the data to to get the scale of our Department.
In a real strodes hammocks stroke, we had 1000 patients last year and we have some 26% of patients receive.
Intravenous tranquilizes and thrombectomy.
As has had been done in 144 patients last year and the trends are going on.
The length of stay is a bit more than 11 days and the mortality rate is a bit lower than 12%, let's say 12%.
It's not known for 15 years, or perhaps the first articles came out some 20 years ago.
That patients benefit from stroke units.
Special Department for stroke from acute interventions as we can we saw in the lecture of Professor Self too early before.
But also from multidisciplinary management, and one of these.
Is also early never rehabilitation.
Now if you go and look for what neurorehabilitation really is, or even rehabilitation medicine if you go into it, you'll get a lot of interesting definitions on the net or in the papers.
But I think the most important thing is that instead of the.
On the course.
Of disease, we deal with the function in order to lessen the to improve the participation of the patients.
Now what are the?
Basic premises of our Never Abilitation team in Ljubljana first.
We always say.
And I think that in in the papers it's not stressed enough that this correlation between different levels of health according to international classification of Functioning is not linear.
I think that it's really important to know because if you work.

As I do in a in a neurological Department and I'm neurologist in Physciatrist and for physciatrist I'm not a real physciatrist an for neurologists, I'm not a real neurologist and you know that it's hard for this real neurologist.
All school neurologist is hard to grasp the idea of this.
Nonlinearity in what stroke means to patients.
New reputation and reputation medicine is a circular process of a team.
Work with goal setting an measurements, an adaptation of goals with patient in a center.
And if you say that the patient in a stroke team or stroke unit is in a center, you have a bit of a problems.
Sam
Problems an that.
Now when you come across the real patient in a in a in a clinical setting, setting and then you go to the library and read a lot.
You have some problems and these problems are this.
Do we really know what patients with stroke need or want?
It's very hard to come across a papers that paper that would deal with that.
And if you go into a lot of papers written in patients with stroke, you'll see that they value independence in activities of daily living.
They value communication.
And they value sex.
And not a lot of work has been done on all of that, but it's improving fast.
So in our 60 bets, we can offer patient six physiotherapists, three occupational therapist respiratory.
Free speech to psychologists.
And we have outsourced dietitian and social worker.
Anne.
This is OK if you take a guidelines from 2003.
Which said they said one physiotherapist for 10 beds.
But if you have now 45 minutes per dysfunction per day, five days a week.
You're a bit in a trouble with our with our team, so.
We struggle.
And that causes some.
Some misunderstandings from time to time, from neurologists from headedness and from members of the team.
Some other ideas that we have is.
Should we really start early?
You know that these are word study and then responses to avert study.
Should we start very early or shouldn't should be Stein?
Three or five or seven days or a month after stroke.
We now believe that early is good.
We also believe that very early is good if you fragment.
Into several actions per day.
Few minutes per meeting.
And we also believe, like a group of Jon Krakauer.
That actually is himmick lesion opens a very.
A period of heightened responsiveness.
This is his group study than not long ago.
Where a mouse.
Gets inflicted stroke.
And then.
If such a mouse is isolated.
They don't get very well in function, but.
If it's put into the usual social environment, they improve pretty much.
But the nice idea of Krakauer's group was what if this isolated mouse gets another stroke?
And then they put her another stroke and put her into its social environment, and they improved functionally a lot.
Actually, they improved as much as the first mouse.
So I think that is approved.
It have to be probably replicated many times, but I think it's approved that the stroke itself opens a special time and this special time is not far away from the stroke.
It's close to stroke.
And so.
We have to ask ourselves, can we influence that we of course believe that with our.
Structured themes and and and physiotherapy and all that that we change patients with stroke.
And yes.
The institutions that receive our admit our patients after us say that our patients are different than from our hospitals, which is a problem on its own, but.
They say that our patients are different.
The in activities of daily living are better.
They don't have.
Stormers they don't have catheters, nothing of that.
And they look better.
However, it's not that easy.
So we start very early in a day or two.
Actually we started admission with dysphagia test.
This pager test again in practice is a problem.
It's very easy.
There's a lot of tests, more or less alike.
Whether you put 50 millimeters or 75 millimeters of water, I don't think it matters really much.
But you come across a problem that you have to see the patient.
Can you see the patient in the first hours of stroke?
If you speak to neurology they would say if because of the article from 2003 that the blood flow falls by 30%.
In she put acute phase of stroke.
If you hit in the head.
So can we do that this major test?
Course in reputation.
We say yes.
Now we know that, at least by any NIH stroke scale 16 we can do it without without any problems.
And we have proofs for that.
We have fragmented our physiotherapy and occupational therapy and speech therapy visits.
254 or five per day and they lost between 3 and 10 minutes every time, which of course brings us a lot of problem.
The.
Realness says that the future therapist just comes and take a look and goes.
So now we have problems that our coworkers don't work a lot.
And that's a culture of the team that is not so easy to get.
We also believe like some others or believe we assume.
That we can.
Widen this period of heightened responsiveness by pharmacotherapy like antidepressants.
We don't give them to everyone but we.
Give them a lot.
And we also believe that this.
That we will move from task specific therapy to this enriched environment.
An enriched experience.
Not a dime.
Now what we really do is a problem and this last few years this mulieres.
The doctor comes to my mind a lot.
The doctors just amuses patients until time does it work?
But in 2009 I think rate it was was the first article that actually people.
Recover by some kind of proportional rule.
Now we have problems here.
If you go into literature, you will see that the rehabilitation literature is highly dominated by motor rehabilitation and by.
Stroke cinemedia and that is not the the real life.
And further on, if you go and really take a study on your own and even if you speak to others.
You see?

That from the whole population of patients in your Department for a classical rehabilitation study, only 9 to 11 patients are really good enough to fulfill the inclusion criteria, so that is not a real life any longer as well.
So.
The proportional recovery model.
This is from crackles group.
Also says that.
Patients recover.
Some around 2/3 or 70% of patients recover pretty predictable.

If you make a test in in this cases for functional test for upper extremity, if you perform the test in the third day after stroke and then again in three months, you can actually predict the result after three months.
So what do we do?
So if I am.
Begging for more.
Coworkers in our new reputation team everyday.
Do I have?
A background for that.
Now we believe, and perhaps some of my colleagues will correct me or give their own opinions, but.
It is in the air that we had at the moment, some 10 to 15% to this.
Recovery model by early rehabilitation, but.
So.
Can we improve that?
And that's that's a big deal.
There's also change in some.
Understandings what?
Influences the.
The outcome.
Anne.
Be beside the hipper acute treatment which is has really changed the deal.
It's also now the therapy that we give.
The the treatment that we give.
And two things that we have now.
Now that we put more emphasis on is sleeping nutrition.
Something that's also a bit hot topic.
So we stop.
Early we set the goals we we keep the track.
Of what patients want for each and every one of them.
We should measure, but we don't.
We don't publish a lot.
With that team.
You know it's it's 11 day.
That's usually eight.
We work on Saturdays too, in in in a new reputation.
But for this short amount of time, if we take the first day or the third day of measurements and the last day of measurements, we take away 1/8 or sometimes 1/4 of the available therapy.
So we have decided not to do the measurements until we get the stuff enough.
And I don't think it will happen soon.
I'm sorry bout that so.
This general ideas I like nice a lot the British guidelines.
This nice save 45 minutes per dysfunction per working day five days a week.
We now know.
That the outcome is better if we offer the therapies seven days a week.
So I think in the future that will become a standard and I that we will have to put more into it.
I also think that the task specific is slowly going out perhaps, and that we will do this more enriched environment and more.
And cognitively abilitation, which take longer then then motor will also become more important.
It is more important now.
In our group we have now employed.
We are now employing 6 psychologists altogether in we're putting more into stroke.
Early supported discharge is another thing that we would we miss a lot.
We have one University rehabilitation center.
And in about 4000 and some strokes in Slovenia.
And mortality rate and all these calculations.
There's about two 2800 patients that would need rehabilitation, a structured, prolonged program, and our University center can offer only.
270 places so we are trying in all sorts of way.
There's a lot of knew still in research phase therapist an we tried to follow the research and sometimes we like to add something.
Our own.
And finally, what are the difficulties that we face and I think most most of the people in this.
Cinderella business like medicine.
So we face the general position of rehabilitation 2 tower three abilitation medicine.
In this.
Competing times for money.
They tell you that they don't have surgery.
They don't have for ultrasounds.
How would they have for psychologist for this?
And as this specific, specific position of never abilitation we.
There's there's some fashion in palliative medicine, and they want your your staff and they start to palliate a patient from the beginning on and so on.
Then there's a very strong role of traditional roles in neurologists and nurses, specially nurses.
An as I have learned, the management if the management change, your program can collapse completely.
So we hope for.
And I think that as clear transfer it a change from pay for service to pay for performance.
And when that happens then every abilitation have will have a stronger role.
Thank you very much.
